text: Antjie Krog (born in 1952) is a writer and teacher from South Africa. She is well known for her Afrikaans poems, her news reporting on the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, and her 1998 book Country of My Skull. In 2004, she became an Extraordinary Professor in the Arts faculty at the University of the Western Cape. == Early life and education == Antjie Krog was born in 1952 into an Afrikaner family of writers. Her mother was Dot Serfontein, a well-known Afrikaans author. She grew up on a farm in Kroonstad, in the Orange Free State. Her writing career started in 1970 when she was still in school. During the apartheid era under John Vorster, she wrote a poem called "My mooi land" ("My beautiful country") for her school magazine. The poem began with the line, "I'm building myself a country where skin colour doesn't matter." It challenged racist ideas and caused a lot of attention in her mostly conservative Afrikaans community. The poem was even mentioned in the national news. Soon after, at the age of seventeen, she published her first book of poems, Dogter van Jefta ("Daughter of Jephta"). The poem "My mooi land" was later translated and published by the African National Congress (ANC) in London, and ANC leader Ahmed Kathrada read it out loud after being freed from prison (Robben Island). Krog earned a BA Honours degree from the University of the Orange Free State in 1976, a Master’s degree in Afrikaans from the University of Pretoria in 1983, and also got a teaching diploma from the University of South Africa. == Career == === 1980s: Poet and activist === During the 1980s and early 1990s, Antjie Krog lived in Kroonstad with her husband and young children. She worked as a teacher at a high school and a teachers' college for Black students. She was also active in politics—attending ANC meetings and protests—and joined the Congress of South African Writers when it was formed in 1987. She once read a poem at a “Free Mandela” rally in the township of Maokeng. This period of her life, including the anger she faced from some white people in her community, is the focus of her first prose book, Relaas van 'n moord (“Account of a Murder”), published in 1995. === 1990s: Journalist at the TRC === In 1993, Krog became the editor of Die Suid-Afrikaan ("The South African"), an Afrikaans current-affairs magazine that no longer exists. From 1995 to 2000, she worked as a radio journalist for the South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC). She led the radio team that reported on the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) between 1996 and 1998. Her experiences covering the TRC became the basis for her well-known book, Country of My Skull (1998). During this time, she used her married name, Antjie Samuel, in her journalism. === 2000s–present: author, academic, and public thinker === In the years since, Krog has written three new poetry books, four prose books, and one book of essays. She has also done several translations, including two from African languages. One of her major works was translating Nelson Mandela’s Long Walk to Freedom into Afrikaans. She also often translates from Dutch to Afrikaans to keep her writing sharp. After publishing Country of My Skull, Krog gave lectures about the TRC in Europe and the U.S. She has also taught translation at Columbia University. She has served as writer-in-residence at the Dutch Foundation for Literature (2019), Ghent University (2020), and Leiden University (2021). Since 2004, Krog has worked as an Extraordinary Professor at the University of the Western Cape and as a research fellow at the university’s Centre for Multilingualism and Diversities Research. She continues to write and publish literary criticism.. == Personal life == Antjie Krog is married to an architect named John Samuel. They have four children—Andries, Susan, Philip, and Willem—and eleven grandchildren. == Poetry == Krog’s first book of poems, Dogter van Jefta (“Daughter of Jephta”), was published in 1970. Since then, she has written many more poetry books. Her poems often reflect her own life, talking about love, the role of an artist, and since the 1980s, race and gender issues. Krog has said that her sixth book, Jerusalemgangers (1985), was her first collection that was fully political. She usually writes in free verse (poetry without regular rhyme or rhythm). Krog’s poetry is well respected in South Africa. She has won the prestigious Hertzog Prize three times, as well as other national awards. Her poems have been translated into many languages, including English, Dutch, and French. Her first English collection was Down to My Last Skin (2000). When reviewing her book Kleur kom nooit alleen nie (2000), critic Leon de Kock said, “She breaks the rules—both sexual and political—and won’t stop trying to speak for the land.” In the novel Diary of a Bad Year by J. M. Coetzee, the main character praises Krog’s poetry, saying: > In Simple English: - “Her theme is a big one: the history of South Africa > during her lifetime. She rises to the challenge with real sincerity, deep > intelligence, and powerful emotional experience. No one in Australia writes > with such intense passion. Antjie Krog’s writing reminds me of Russian > writers—life can be hard, but brave voices like hers still shine.” In > American English: - (Her theme is a large one: historical experience in the > South Africa of her lifetime. Her capacities as a poet have grown in > response to the challenge, refusing to be dwarfed. Utter sincerity backed > with an acute, feminine intelligence, and a body of heart-rending experience > to draw upon... No one in Australia writes at a comparable white heat. The > phenomenon of Antjie Krog strikes me as quite Russian. In South Africa, as > in Russia, life may be wretched; but how the brave spirit leaps to respond! == Prose and non-fiction == Antjie Krog is best known for her book Country of My Skull (1998), which is about her time reporting on the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC). The book mixes personal stories and real events. It was later turned into a movie in 2004, starring Samuel L. Jackson and Juliette Binoche. Her second English book, A Change of Tongue (2003), looks at how South Africa and her own life have changed since the country’s first democratic elections in 1994. The book blends true stories, poetry, and fiction. It includes her own experiences and the stories of others, focusing on identity, truth, and healing. The title has both personal and political meanings. It talks about how Afrikaans is being used less in public and how Krog herself started writing more in English. She also writes about her meetings with Nelson Mandela when she was translating his life story into Afrikaans, and how she feels about Afrikaans, the language linked to Apartheid. Another book, Begging to be Black (2009), is written in a similar way and talks about similar topics. It’s considered the third book in an unofficial series that includes Country of My Skull and A Change of Tongue. Krog also helped write There Was This Goat (2009), along with Nosisi Mpolweni and Kopano Ratele. It looks at the testimony of a woman named Notrose Nobomvu Konile during the TRC. The woman spoke in Xhosa, and her words seemed confusing when translated into English. The authors try to understand what she really meant. Krog says her writing is influenced by South African authors like J. M. Coetzee and Njabulo Ndebele, and also by African stories translated from local languages. She says these influences helped her see the world differently and gave her the tools to understand and write about it deeply. > African writings helped me understand a way of seeing the world that I had > always lived with, but never fully noticed—how deep, powerful, and beautiful > it is. Coetzee’s work gave me the tools to study and understand it better. == Play and theatre adaptations == Antjie Krog wrote one stage play called Waarom is dié wat voor toyi-toyi altyd so vet? ("Why are those who toyi-toyi in front always so fat?"). It was first performed in 1999 at the Aardklop Arts Festival and directed by Marthinus Basson. The play was nominated for seven awards at the FNB Vita Regional Theatre Awards in Bloemfontein, including Best Production and Best Script for a New South African Play. According to Krog, the play is about how two races try to start a conversation with each other. Krog also translated the play Mamma Medea by Tom Lanoye into Afrikaans. It was performed in South Africa in 2002, also directed by Basson. Another one of her works, A Change of Tongue, was translated into Afrikaans as ’n Ander tongval. It was turned into a stage play by Saartjie Botha and directed by Jaco Bouwer in 2008. == Plagiarism allegation == In 2006, poet Stephen Watson, who was head of the English department at the University of Cape Town, accused Krog of plagiarism. In an article in the magazine New Contrast, he said Krog’s book Country of My Skull copied phrases from a 1976 essay by Ted Hughes called "Myth and Education". He also claimed that her 2004 book Die sterre sê 'tsau'—a collection of indigenous poetry—copied the idea from a similar book he had published in 1991. Krog denied the accusations. She said she had never read the Ted Hughes essay before publishing Country of My Skull, and that she had clearly given credit to her sources in Die sterre sê 'tsau'. == Books and writings == === Poetry === * Dogter van Jefta (1970) * Januarie-suite (1972) * Beminde Antarktika (1974) * Mannin (1974) * Otters in Bronslaai (1981) * Jerusalemgangers (1985) * Lady Anne (1989;
